questions.text: What is the name of this medium shown below, which is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium has been shown in the given image.

It is a type of selective and indicator media. 

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

It is a differential media as well, as it brings out different characteristics of bacteria. 

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

 

On Deoxycholate citrate media and XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) , colonies show black heads due to H2S production.

Other options:

Option 1) PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis. It is a selective medium consisting of polymyxin, lysozyme, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and thallous acetate added to heart infusion agar.

Option 2) XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar is a selective growth medium used in the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species. It has a pH of 7.4, with a bright pink or red colour due to the indicator phenol red. Sugar fermentation lowers the pH and the phenol red indicator turns yellow. Most gut bacteria, like Salmonella, can ferment the sugar xylose to produce acid but Shigella colonies cannot and therefore remain red.

Salmonella also metabolise thiosulfate to produce H2S or hydrogen sulphide, which leads to the formation of colonies with black centers and allows them to be differentiated from the Shigella colonies.

Option 4) Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to laboratory.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium which prevent microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as oxidation reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colourless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

questions.text: The Fernandez reaction of lepromin test is read at _________
questions.solution:
The Fernandez reaction or the early reaction of the lepromin test is read at 48 hours.

Lepromin test is a prognostic test used in the classification of Leprosy. It has no diagnostic purpose.

  • It involves performing an intradermal injection of the lepromin antigen (synthesized from M. leprae) on the flexor surface of the forearm.
  • It is an indicator of cell-mediated immunity and hence may be positive in normal individuals as well. 
  • A positive test indicates good cell-mediated immunity and towards Tuberculoid side of the spectrum
  • A negative test indicates poor cell-mediated immunity and towards the Lepromatous side of the spectrum.

There are two possible responses:

  • The early reaction of Fernandez - Positive within 48-72 hours if there is the erythema measuring >10 mm
  • Late Reaction of Mitsuda - Positive at 21 days if there is the onset of a papule measuring 5 mm or more (A better indicator of Cell-Mediated Immunity)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's.

Amputation at the level distal tibia and fibula 0.6cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. It involves the removal of both medial and lateral malleoli.

questions.text: Which of the following would you mention as the most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray, that a patient should watch out for?
questions.solution:
The most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray is a bitter taste.

Triptans are selective 5HT 1B/1D agonists. They are indicated in the management of acute attacks of migraine.

The side effect of Triptans: Commonly, minor side effects are seen with triptans in the acute treatment of migraine. The most common side effect of sumatriptan nasal spray is a bitter taste.

After subcutaneous injection of sumatriptan - irritation can occur at the site of injection (transient mild pain, stinging, or burning sensations). Triptans can cause paresthesias, asthenia, and fatigue. Pressure, tightness, or pain in the chest, neck, and jaw have also been noted.

Coronary artery disease/ IHD/ Arrhythmia: Serious cardiac events are rare, but have been associated with the use of 5HT1 agonists, including coronary artery vasospasm, transient myocardial ischemia, atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, and myocardial infarction, mainly in patients with risk factors for coronary artery disease.

Hypertensive and Ischemic Diseases: The triptans are contraindicated in patients with a history of ischemic or vasospastic coronary artery disease (history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks), cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease, hemiplegic or basilar migraines, or ischemic bowel diseases. Triptans are also contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

Hepatic/Renal Conditions: Naratriptan is contraindicated in patients with severe renal or hepatic impairment (rizatriptan should also be used with caution). Eletriptan is contraindicated in hepatic disease.

Serotonin syndrome: Rarely, triptans can cause serotonin syndrome (due to excess of serotonin at 5HT receptors), particularly when used in combination with SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, and MAO inhibitors.

Drug Interactions: All triptans are contraindicated in patients with simultaneous or prior exposure to ergot alkaloids, other triptans or 5HT agonists, SSRIs, and SNRIs. Almotriptan, rizatriptan, sumatriptan, and zolmitriptan are contraindicated with MAO inhibitor (within the preceding 2 weeks).

Pregnancy and Breastfeeding: The triptans are classified as a pregnancy category C drug ( there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women and are to be used during pregnancy only if the potential benefit justifies a potential risk to the fetus). They should be used with caution in nursing mothers (sumatriptan has the best safety profile in pregnancy).

questions.text: A 30-year-old  with low mood and lethargy is brought to the ER after he fell whilst trying to get up from the bed. The findings on his hands and gums have been shown below. Vitals revealed PR:100bpm, BP: 110/70mmHg in the supine position, 90/60mmHg on standing. RBS is 120mg/dl. ABG revealed Na-120mEq/L, K-6mEq/L. How would you manage this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of Acute adrenal crisis in Addison's disease. It is treated with IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus, followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone.
Points suggestive of Addison's disease: Low mood and lethargy, hyperpigmentation on gums, dorsum of hands and other exposed areas, postural hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia.

Acute adrenal crisis may be precipitated by any illness, stress, infection, hyperthyroidism contributing to increased utilization of glucocorticoids.

It can be confirmed by the ACTH stimulation test.

It is treated with IV infusion of saline and hydrocortisone bolus. Followed by a maintenance dose of hydrocortisone. Mineralocorticoid replacement, and adrenal androgen replacement is required in the definite management.

The most common cause of Addison’s disease is:

  • Tuberculosis in developing countries 
  • Autoimmune (Idiopathic atrophy) in developed countries

Other options:
Option B:  Thyrotoxicosis : The scenario will not have low BP or postural hypotension as in this case. It will have symptoms of increased metabolism, increased appetite, increased pulse,BP.

Option C: Acute labyrinthitis patients might present with a history of falls and will complain of vertigo. It will not have features of hyponatremia or hypotension.

questions.text: The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes all except _____.
questions.solution:
The classical triad of amniotic fluid embolism includes the following:

  • Hypotension
  • Hypoxia
  • Severe consumptive coagulopathy 

Predisposing conditions:

  • Rapid labor
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  • Tears into uterine and other large pelvic veins
  • Older maternal age
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Labor induction or augmentation
  • Eclampsia
  • Cesarean/forceps/vacuum delivery
  • Placental abruption/placenta previa
  • Hydramnios 

Clinical picture:

Late stage of labor/immediate postpartum: Sudden gasping for air → Sudden seizures/cardiorespiratory arrest→ massive hemorrhage due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with an acute attack of gout after alcohol intake. Identify the underlying mechanism:

choices.text: Impaired biliary excretion of uric acid
Increased urate production from damaged hepatocytes
Reduced renal excretion of uric acid

questions.solution:
Alcohol intake precipitates acute gout by decreasing the renal excretion of uric acid.

Following alcohol intake, alcohol and aldehyde dehydrogenase metabolise ethanol to acetyl CoA and reduce NAD+ to NADH in the process. The increased NADH/NAD+ ratio in turn catalyses the conversion of pyruvate to lactate and causes metabolic acidosis. Lactic acid competes with uric acid for excretion in the renal tubules and leads to hyperuricemia precipitating an attack of acute gout.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the left eye. Her MRI head is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and MRI showing tram track sign is suggestive of optic nerve meningioma.

Primary optic nerve meningioma arises from the arachnoid sheath of the optic nerve.

CT or MRI shows tram track sign. It is defined as the relative hypoattenuation of the optic nerve on CT or reduced signal on post gadolinium MRI due to peripheral enhancement of the tumor around the nerve.

The tram-track sign is useful in the differentiation between optic nerve meningioma and optic nerve gliomas.

CT may be also useful in detecting calcification within the meningioma which is specific to optic nerve meningioma and not seen in optic nerve glioma.

questions.text: A lady came to the hospital after fighting with her husband. She reports that she is unable to speak. However, all neurological and physical examinations are normal, and she does not seem concerned about her condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
La-belle indifference is seen in conversion disorder. It is the absence of concern towards one’s problem despite the apparent severe disability.

Conversion disorder is also called functional neurological symptom disorder, and there is no bodily cause involved in this condition. A conversion reaction is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial stress. Most of the patients have a history of a traumatic event in childhood. The symptoms or deficits of conversion disorder are not intentionally produced. It is more commonly seen in females.

Primary gain refers to keeping internal conflicts outside of awareness and the relief from stress. Secondary gain refers to the attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of being sick. If the secondary gain is intentional, then it would lead to the diagnosis of malingering. A related phenomenon is la belle indifference, in which the patient is not concerned about the serious symptoms.

Symptoms of conversion disorder:

  • One or two neurologic symptoms affecting the voluntary or sensory function
  • Must have psychologic factors associated with the onset or exacerbation of the symptoms.
  • Mutism, blindness, and paralysis are the most common symptoms.
  • Sensory system: Anesthesia and paresthesia
  • Motor system: Abnormal movements, gait disturbance (astasia abasia), weakness, paralysis, tics, jerks, etc.
  • Central nervous system: Pseudo-seizures

Other Options:

Option A: Adjustment reaction is a psychological response to an identifiable stressor that results in the development of clinically significant emotional or behavioral symptoms. The condition develops within 3 months of exposure to the stressor and lasts no longer than 6 months after the stressor or its consequences have ended. Notably, the emotional or behavioral symptoms must be out of proportion to the stressor when considering cultural and contextual factors.

Option B: Somatic symptom disorder is the presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder. It is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms.

Option C:Malingering is the intentional falsification of physical or psychological symptoms to achieve some practical gain such as financial compensation, avoidance of criminal responsibility or military service, or leave from work. 

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Presence of primary and secondary gain
  • La-belle indifference: refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva and inspiratory stridor is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute epiglottitis. The symptoms of drooling of saliva, inspiratory stridor and fever are suggestive of epiglottitis. The lateral X-ray of neck shows enlarged and edematous epiglottis or “thumb” sign.

Retropharyngeal and parapharyngeal abscess present with neck stiffness, trismus and muffled voice while barking cough and hoarseness are seen in tracheolaryngobronchitis (croup).

Retropharyngeal abscess would show widened pre-vertebral space on X-ray whereas croup is characterized by steeple sign. Parapharyngeal abscess is poorly defined on X ray and is best diagnosed on CT.

Acute epiglottitis

  • Microbiology: Streptococcus > Hemophilus influenzae b
  • Median age: 6-12 years
  • Cinical features: Distress (Inspiratory stidor, tripod positioning), Dysphagia and Drooling
  • X ray findings: Thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis), loss of vallecular space
  • Management: Antibiotics, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

  • Microbiology: viral infection
  • Median age: 6 months to 6 years
  • Clinical features: barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low grade fever
  • X-ray findings: “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing
  • Management: Nebulized racemic epinephrine

Retropharyngeal abscess:

  • Microbiology: Polymicrobial (streptococcus pyogenes, staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes)
  • Median age: 6 months – 6 years
  • Clinical features: Fever, odonyphagia/dysphagia, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice and trismus.
  • X-ray findings: Widened pre-vertebral space
  • Management: Intravenous antibiotics + Surgical drainage, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Parapharyngeal abscess presents similar to Retropharyngeal abscess and is best diagnosed on CT.

Steeple sign – Croup

Widened prevertebral space-Retropharyngeal abscess

Note:

The most common cause of epiglottitis:
In India - Hemophilus influenza.
Rest of the World - Strep. pneumonia.

Though Nelson mentions that H.influenza is not the most common cause of this condition, the latest edition of O.P Ghai still mentions H.influenza as the most common cause of acute epiglottitis. 
What it means is that, in India, even though cases of H. influenza are coming down due to increased vaccine coverage, still H. influenza remains the leading cause of acute epiglottitis in India.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

X-ray neck shows steeple sign

Toxic child, drooling saliva
